a \prec b \; \wedge \; b \preceq a \quad \overset{?}{\Rightarrow} \quad a \sim b.

children.value: As with ordinals, we would like to choose a system of representatives for the equivalence classes under

children.html: ∼\sim∼

children.value: suggests to use ordinals (which we can compare using the well-ordering of ordinals). We therefore assume the Axiom of Choice (so every set has a well-ordering). One issue that remains is that a set can have well-orderings of different lengths (as we saw in the case of the natural numbers

children.html: N\NatN

children.value: ). But since the ordinals are well-ordered, we can choose the

We know the set of reals is uncountable, so at this time we are able to conclude

children.value: What can we say about the cardinality of unions, products, etc.?

children.html: ∣R×R∣=∣R∣|\R \times \R| = |\R|∣R×R∣=∣R∣

children.value: This is an instance of a more general result. We can define arithmetic operation on cardinals by looking at the cardinalities of the corresponding set theoretic operations.

children.html: κ+λ=∣(κ×{0})∪(λ×{1})∣(disjoint union)κ⋅λ=∣κ×λ∣(product)κλ=∣{f ⁣:f:λ→κ}∣(exponentiation)\begin{align*} \kappa + \lambda \quad & = \quad |(\kappa \times \{0\}) \cup (\lambda \times \{1\})| & \qquad (\text{disjoint union}) \\ \kappa \cdot \lambda \quad & = \quad |\kappa \times \lambda | & \qquad (\text{product})\\ \kappa^{\lambda} \quad & = \quad |\{f \colon f: \lambda \to \kappa \}| & \qquad (\text{exponentiation}) \end{align*}κ+λκ⋅λκλ​=∣(κ×{0})∪(λ×{1})∣=∣κ×λ∣=∣{f:f:λ→κ}∣​(disjoint union)(product)(exponentiation)​

children.value: Verify that for finite cardinalities, the operations defined above agree with the usual arithmetic operations on natural numbers.
It turns out for infinite cardinals,

children.html: +++

children.value: are trivial, which is a consequence of the following theorem.

children.html: κ⋅κ=κ.\kappa \cdot \kappa = \kappa.κ⋅κ=κ.
